awd_titl_txt: Competitive Polymer Hydration and Confinement in Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computer modeling, theoretical research and education to apply the principles of statistical physics to gain insights on competitive polymer hydration in nanomaterials. Polymers are long chain-like molecules, some of which can form weak electrostatic bonds, known as hydrogen bonds, with water or other solvents. Many nanotechnological applications such as nanomedicine, purification, and sensing employ biocompatible water-soluble polymers that may be grafted to surfaces or part of a larger self-assembled supramolecular structure. To a large extent the properties of these nanomaterials depend on polymer hydration, that is, the interactions between the polymers and the surrounding water molecules. Competitive polymer hydration reflects the fact that there is a competition for the formation of polymer-water hydrogen bonds with other chemical components of the system. This competition can lead to changes in polymer size and shape, which may affect the properties of the nanomaterial. The PI aims to use computer simulation to investigate the factors affecting polymer hydration and the organization of the surrounding water in polymers grafted to surfaces or forming larger self-assembled structures. The PI will study competitive hydration involving the presence of additional solvents, such as alcohols, and the presence of biologically relevant simple sugars, such as fructose and glucose, which are typically encountered in many nanomaterial applications. Fundamental understanding of polymer hydration is essential for proper functioning of nanomaterials, designing new responsive materials, and optimizing their performance. This research will contribute to theoretical understanding of the properties of polymer-grafted nanostructures and create a basis for comparison of competitive hydration in nanostructures of different geometries, for example planar vs. curved surfaces, exposed to multicomponent solutions. This project will also provide insights into molecular transport through nanopores thereby bridging polymer science and biophysics. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in modern simulation methods and data analysis. The results of this research will enhance graduate courses on polymer and soft matter physics as well as stimulate interest in STEM graduate and undergraduate research and education. 


TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computer simulation and theoretical research, and education to understand the effects of competitive solvation and nanoconfinement of water-soluble polymers grafted to surfaces of different curvature. Solubility of many macromolecules depend on hydrogen bonding with water. Hydrogen bonding is a highly competitive interaction and susceptible to external conditions, which may alter the balance between acceptors competing for donors or vice versa. The outcomes of such an intricate balance are often hard to anticipate and hydration is rather difficult to measure experimentally. Computer simulations are a good tool for studying hydration and hydrogen bonding. Using largescale atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, the PI will investigate water structuring and hydration of polyethylene oxide grafted to solid nanopores, the effect of synthetic and carbohydrate co-solvents on polymer conformation, and the properties of polymer brushes grafted to convex, planar and concave gold surfaces or as part of a self-assembled micelle structure. The research group will investigate proton donating and proton accepting co-solvents and analyze hydration dynamics and competition for hydrogen bonding between inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonding with polymer brushes leading to conformational changes and to triggering pore opening/closing in a solvent or temperature-dependent manner. The influence of polymer length, grafting density, size, surface curvature, co-solvent concentration, shape, hydrophobicity and chemical origin, whether synthetic or biological, on competitive hydration will be systematically studied. Based on simulation data analysis, experimentally testable predictions will be made regarding co-solvent-triggered changes in the polymer brush properties including control over the polymer-grafted nanopore transport or surface interaction of polymer-grafted nanoparticles and micelles, as used in biomedical applications. This project will provide ample opportunity for graduate and undergraduate student training in modern computational skills which can be applied in different scientific and nanotechnological areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Self-assembled or grafted soft biocompatible water-soluble macromolecules are employed in many nanotechnological applications including nanomedicine, nanofluidics, purification and sensing technologies. The properties of these nanomaterials depend on interactions between the macromolecules and the surrounding solution including water and cosolvents, i.e. on competitive hydration. A fundamental understanding of macromolecular hydration and the ability to control it is important for proper functioning of nanomaterials and designing new responsive nanomaterials that operate in aqueous environments. In this project atomistic molecular dynamics simulations have been employed to investigate competitive hydration of amphiphilic macromolecules in solution, in self-assembled nanostructures and grafted to concave and convex solid surfaces, including nanopores. We investigated how subtle structural changes can influence the temperature dependence of hydration in water-soluble polymers by comparing the technologically important polyethers polyethylene (PEO) and polypropylene oxide (PPO). We have analyzed how water structuring and the presence of cosolvent affect conformation, hydration and dynamics of amphiphilic polymers in solution, within nanostructures and at grafted surfaces including the impact of nanoconfinement. Temperature- or cosolvent-induced conformational changes and in particular the coil-globule transition of polypropylene oxide in aqueous solution has been investigated by atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. A new mechanism of the transition has been identified: formation of nucleation sites originated from the statistical distribution of monomers hydrogen bonded with water along the chain with longer chains exhibiting longer sequences of non-hydrogen bonded units facilitates chain collapse at a lower temperature, in agreement with experimental data. The observation of the statistical origin of nucleation site formation for the coil-globule transition of an amphiphilic macromolecule may have important implication for development of smart materials involving such polymers and even may have some similarity to protein folding. We have also demonstrated that hydrogen bonding and a polymer’s capability to maintain its hydration shell are the key factors in polymer responsiveness to external triggers, e.g. temperature or co-solvent, factors that should be taken into consideration upon responsive material design and applications. The results of atomistic molecular dynamics simulations of co-solvents of different hydrophobicity and hydrogen bonding capability interacting with self-assembled amphiphilic polymer micelles have demonstrated different cosolvent localization and the extent of penetration into the micelle cores   which is relevant for applications of polymer micelles including drug loading and delivery. Using atomistic molecular dynamics simulations we investigated the effect of grafting density, polymer length and pore-size on polymer conformation in polymer-grafted gold nanopores. We demonstrated that an increase of pore curvature (e.g. diminished pore size) results in considerable polymer crowding within the pore, which leads to an increase of the effective grafting density. An analytical relation that describes this effect was developed.  Accordingly, a considerable difference in polymer distribution has been observed for concave nanopores, planar and convex surfaces. Flow through the polymer-grafted nanopores has also been investigated. For polymer-grafted nanopores we have demonstrated the various mechanisms by which addition of a cosolvent changes the morphology of a grafted PEO layer. Furthermore, co-solvent-induced changes in polymer conformation also affect the dynamics of water and cosolvents within the pore which can be exploited for regulating material transport or translocation through polymer-grafted nanopore devices. The obtained results for the effects of cosolvent addition on the morphological change of PEO grafted to gold nanopores provide a fundamental understanding of the principles of cosolvent-induced polymer-grafted nanopore control. The results of the research have been published in the leading journals in the polymer physics field: Phys. Rev. Letters, Macromolecules, Macromolecular Rapid Communications, Journal of Computational Chemistry and presented at international conferences. We have developed code for topology initiation for polymer-grafted structures and obtained an improved force-field for PPO that has been openly shared via GitHub. Two PhD students have successfully defended their dissertations based on the research supported by this grant and started working for a US company and a national laboratory respectively. One more graduate student and two undergraduate students received training in molecular dynamics simulations working on the project. The results obtained for this project were used to demonstrate concepts of statistical and polymer physics in undergraduate and graduate classes as well as to stimulate the interest of underrepresented undergraduate students in pursuing STEM education.
